column1: message
"Oh was that due this week?" The MFA student you’re working with prioritized their own work and missed a crucial deadline. Go back 2 spaces.
Your department is skeptical of your project. "How will we divide credit between all the people involved?" asks your chair. Go back 2 spaces.
The Ph.D. student you’re working with is struggling to balance course work, their own research, and their project work. Go back 2 spaces.
It’s midterms season! Progress slows to a crawl as your student workers focus on studying and taking exams. Remain in place until your next turn.
Working on a public-facing project gives your research team a clear sense of shared purpose. Move forward 6 spaces.
Congratulations! Your project has been awarded a major federal grant, giving your team two years’ of runway. Move forward 10 spaces.
The grants office said you weren’t eligible to work with a grants consultant, but you find a way to technically meet their requirements. Move forward 2 spaces.
“Aha!” You and your team have a lightbulb moment after your software developer shares a prototype. Move forward 8 spaces.
You and your team disagree about how to structure research priorities. Remain in place until your next turn.
A collaborator from outside your field tries to teach you something that is foundational to your discipline. Roll your eyes and go back 1 space.
You’re invited to participate in a special issue. Reading papers from other scholars helps you refine the project’s methodology. Move forward 6 spaces.
“We don’t need to make it so complicated. A thesis is just the paper topic.” You and your collaborators can’t agree on some basic definitions. Go back 2 spaces.
Your ability to articulate the “so-what” of the project helps your collaborators see why this research is relevant. Move forward 8 spaces.
You get to learn how to fly a drone! But this isn’t relevant to your project research. Remain in place until your next turn.
After listening to your collaborators share their on-the-ground experiences, you all agree to revise the project goals. Move forward 8 spaces.

You and the other humanists leave the meeting in high spirits. You had so many wonderful ideas! Everyone is excited about the project! It will totally change the field! But no one told the grad students building the project software what to prioritize. They try to decide amongst themselves and end up disagreeing. You only realize this at your next project meeting… a month later. Remain in place until your next turn.
Oh. Whose responsibility was that? It would have been great if you had figured this out before your meeting with the dean! Go back 3 spaces.
Meeting every two weeks helps you and your collaborators maintain momentum. Move forward 8 spaces.
You have to learn how to create a Gantt chart for a grant proposal. This is a hassle, but it also lets you adjust the project timeline to something more feasible. Move forward 2 spaces.

“It’s simple. We just load the proposal documents into Cayuse, then route them with Cayuse SP, and then the DCG signs the MOU, and everything gets uploaded to Grants.gov.” You let go and trust that your department’s pre-award administrator knows what they’re talking about. Move forward 2 spaces.
It’s summer break! Progress slows to a crawl as your student workers focus on internships. Remain in place until your next turn.
It’s time for finals! Progress slows to a crawl as your student workers focus on studying and taking exams. Remain in place until your next turn.

You test out the project in a colleague’s class. Their students offer surprisingly helpful feedback and you suddenly see why so many people have been confused about a key part of the project. Move forward 4 spaces.
You test out the project in a colleague’s class. But only four of their students complete the post-project survey. Go back 1 space.
A senior colleague declines to share their grant application materials. Remain in place until your next turn.
Your team faces difficulties in coordinating schedules and finding common meeting times. It takes extra effort to align everyone's availability. Skip a turn while you work out a meeting schedule.
A key team member receives a prestigious fellowship opportunity. Their absence creates a temporary setback. Go back 2 spaces.

While browsing at a used bookstore, you come across a quirky monograph from the 1980s. It’s not from your field, but you’re intrigued by the title and first few pages. It ends up helping you explain an important facet of the project. Move forward 4 spaces.
All your students turn in their final essays on time, giving you time to quickly grade them and get back to project work. Move forward 2 spaces.
You and one of your collaborators have noticed that some other people at your institution are working on similar projects. You two start an informal works-in-progress series. Move forward 4 spaces.
